line_1: And Nature's smiles bode nought of sorrow:
line_2: While birds yet sing their first good-morrow,

line_1: And banish'd every thought of sorrow
line_2: By gaily pointing to to-morrow.

line_1: Poor wretch! can he feel without heart-rending sorrow,
line_2: The Infidel then sees no joyous to-morrow,

line_1: One day reigns Tragedy, — all gloom and sorrow;
line_2: Then, shift the scenes — and enter Farce to-morrow.

line_1: And eats To-day with inward Sorrow,
line_2: And Dread of fancy'd Want To-morrow.

line_1: It falls for those yet doomed to sorrow;
line_2: Who mourn the past, nor hope the morrow.

line_1: After fretted, pouting sorrow,
line_2: Sweet will be thy smile to-morrow;

line_1: 'Tis not for the happy, come daughter of sorrow,
line_2: Where lost in the past, nor regarding to-morrow,

line_1: We heap up in sin and in sorrow!
line_2: Is not life to be over to-morrow?

line_1: The heart when fill'd with sorrow
line_2: Nor can that cheat to-morrow

line_1: My Lady was disturb'd: new Sorrow!
line_2: Which Hans must answer for to Morrow.

line_1: My Lord of Killala, I find to my Sorrow,
line_2: I can't have the Honour I hop'd for, Tomorrow.

line_1: Depends our Human Joy, or Sorrow:
line_2: Alas! no Eye-brows for To-morrow.

line_1: To day, indeed, his portion's pain and sorrow;
line_2: But joy and ease are hoarded for tomorrow.

line_1: Be it business, love, or sorrow,
line_2: Bid them call again to-morrow,

line_1: Courage, Friend; To-day is your Period of Sorrow;
line_2: And Things will go better, believe Me, To-morrow.

line_1: O where is the splendour can shine away sorrow,
line_2: Did riches e'er purchase the loan of to-morrow,

line_1: The light of Heaven could banish half my sorrow,
line_2: Though, pleasure shine not in the expected morrow,

line_1: Inur'd to every sorrow;
line_2: That bleeds afresh to-morrow.

line_1: Has struggl'd with continu'd Sorrow,
line_2: The desp'rate Bett upon To-morrow.

line_1: The Justice of thy Cloe's Sorrow.
line_2: Such I, alas! may be to Morrow:

line_1: He fasts in Rapture, as of late in Sorrow;
line_2: For who can eat, that's to be rich to-morrow?

line_1: Madam, I hear, and hear with Sorrow,
line_2: That we're to lose Your Grace To-morrow;

line_1: Now I mourn, o'erwhelm'd with sorrow,
line_2: Pond'ring sharpens ev'ry arrow,

line_1: Urg'd that, the Day he wrought her to this Sorrow,
line_2: He Vow'd, that he wou'd marry her To-Morrow.

line_1: And took his leave, with signs of sorrow,
line_2: Despairing of his fee to-morrow.

line_1: The giant hand of sorrow.
line_2: And leave to Heaven the morrow;
